title: Mind the GAP
text:
Mind the GAP 0 comments 
No. I'm not referring to the warning heard by Londoners as they board the cars on the Underground. Rather, I'm talking about the Great Allegheny Passage, or GAP as it is commonly known. The GAP is a trail in western Pennsylvania that offers 150 miles of biking and hiking between Pittsburgh and Cumberland, Md. Built on a former railroad bed, the trail runs along winding rivers, through the shaded woods and valleys, and past numerous small towns providing a great biking experience without having to compete with motorized vehicles. My wife and I recently spent three days riding the entire length of the GAP and had a wonderful time. The experience brought to mind the expression "You may not be able to buy happiness, but you can buy a bicycle and that's pretty close." 
First and foremost, people riding the trail are a happy lot. We saw families with kids - some even on bikes with training wheels - out for a ride having a great time. We saw elderly couples enjoying the trail on a pleasant afternoon. We met other "through riders" who, like us, were tackling the entire length of the trail. And while we sometimes shared war stories and compared aches and pains, there was an underlying sense of joy and satisfaction that shone through these conversations. kAm%96 vp! 3@2DED D@>6 @7 E96 7:?6DE D46?6CJ @7 2?J EC2:= @?
